elements.content: Four uranyl coordination polymers [UO2(C6H8O4)­(H2O)2]­(C18H12N6)2 (1), [UO2(C8H4O4)­(H2O)2]­(C18H12N6)2 (2), Na­[(UO2)­(C12H6O4)2]­(C18H13N6)­·H2O (3), and Na­[(UO2)­(C16H8O4)­(C6H3NO2)]­(C18H12N6)­·H2O (4) containing aliphatic (adipic acid) or aromatic linkers (1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC), 1,4-napthalene dicarboxylic acid (NDC), anthracene 9,10-dicarboxylic acid (ADC)) were synthesized and characterized using single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, and luminescence spectroscopy. The π-stacking distances or the number of π–π interactions present between trispyridyltriazine (TPTZ) guests or the host framework in 1–4 may be affected by the size of the O-donor linker (adipic acid < BDC < NDC < ADC). Luminescence studies show that substitution between adipic acid and BDC influences the emission of 1 and 2, in which the emission of 1 shows a red shift relative to that of 2. Uranyl emission was not observed in 3 and 4, and may be attributed to the position of the NDC and ADC triplet state relative to the emissive uranyl species.

The π-stacking distances or the number of π-π interactions present between trispyridyltriazine (TPTZ) guests or the host framework in 1-4 may be affected by the size of the O-donor linker (adipic acid < BDC < NDC < ADC). Luminescence studies show that substitution between adipic acid and BDC influences the emission of 1 and 2, in which the emission of 1 shows a red shift relative to that of 2. Uranyl emission was not observed in 3 and 4, and may be attributed to the position of the NDC and ADC triplet state relative to the emissive uranyl species.

elements.content: A series of uranyl coordination polymers using differently sized O-donor dicarboxylates (adipic acid, BDC, NDC, ADC) and a N-donor trispyridyltriazine (TPTZ) guest were synthesized and characterized. Systematic variations of the local and global structure are influenced by the size of the O-donor, including π−π distances between TPTZ guests or between an uranyl-host to TPTZ molecules. Luminescence studies suggest the choice of O-donors influences the observed emission.
elements.clean_text: A series of uranyl coordination polymers using differently sized O-donor dicarboxylates (adipic acid, BDC, NDC, ADC) and a N-donor trispyridyltriazine (TPTZ) guest were synthesized and characterized. Systematic variations of the local and global structure are influenced by the size of the O-donor, including π-π distances between TPTZ guests or between an uranyl-host to TPTZ molecules. Luminescence studies suggest the choice of O-donors influences the observed emission.

elements.content: Systematic pairings of N-donor and O-donor ligands with uranyl centers have been shown to promote a wide range of uranyl coordination polymers (CPs) with interesting structural motifs and photoluminescent properties. Such an approach was used successfully in our earlier studies, where bidentate N-donor bipyridine (BPY) ligands, when paired with the O-donor linker thiophene 2,5-dicarboxylic acid (TDC), resulted in a family of uranyl CPs that crystallize as either chains or two-dimensional sheets. We highlighted that coordination of N-donors or its participation as guest species is dependent on the position of bulky substituents on the pyridyl rings, thus influencing the local and global structures of uranyl-bearing TDC materials. Further, we noted that the luminescent properties in these materials are influenced by coordination or noncoordination of N-donor species.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Systematic pairings of N-donor and O-donor ligands with uranyl centers have been shown to promote a wide range of uranyl coordination polymers (CPs) with interesting structural motifs and photoluminescent properties. Such an approach was used successfully in our earlier studies, where bidentate N-donor bipyridine (BPY) ligands, when paired with the O-donor linker thiophene 2,5-dicarboxylic acid (TDC), resulted in a family of uranyl CPs that crystallize as either chains or two-dimensional sheets. We highlighted that coordination of N-donors or its participation as guest species is dependent on the position of bulky substituents on the pyridyl rings, thus influencing the local and global structures of uranyl-bearing TDC materials. Further, we noted that the luminescent properties in these materials are influenced by coordination or noncoordination of N-donor species.

elements.content: Our present efforts endeavored to expand this approach by systematically pairing TPTZ with variously sized O-donors, namely, adipic acid, benzene 1,4-dicarboxylic acid (BDC), naphthalene 1,4-dicarboxylic acid (NDC), and anthracene 9,10-dicarboxylic acid (ADC) (). Interestingly, we note that the TPTZ molecules do not coordinate to the uranyl centers when these O-donors are used and instead behave as “guests” with varying degrees of π–π interactions between them.
elements.clean_text: Our present efforts endeavored to expand this approach by systematically pairing TPTZ with variously sized O-donors, namely, adipic acid, benzene 1,4-dicarboxylic acid (BDC), naphthalene 1,4-dicarboxylic acid (NDC), and anthracene 9,10-dicarboxylic acid (ADC) (). Interestingly, we note that the TPTZ molecules do not coordinate to the uranyl centers when these O-donors are used and instead behave as "guests" with varying degrees of π-π interactions between them.

elements.clean_text: 1  O-Donor Dicarboxylates and TPTZ Guest Used in This Study

elements.content: The O-donor linkers explored in the current study were chosen in order to explore how O-donor size, in combination with TPTZ, influences the local and global structure. This idea has been well-explored in uranyl CPs regarding linker flexibility and rigidity, in which the choice of O-donor dicarboxylates may allow the construction of materials with interesting topologies. For example, the study of linker flexibility on uranyl structures using adipic acid or the study of linker rigidity on uranyl structures using BDC, NDC, and ADC has been documented. Moreover, the number of aromatic rings and the π-conjugation associated within such linkers may potentially enhance the number of noncovalent interactions (namely, π–π interactions) present within uranyl CPs and potentially direct the assembly of uranyl architectures.
elements.clean_text: The O-donor linkers explored in the current study were chosen in order to explore how O-donor size, in combination with TPTZ, influences the local and global structure. This idea has been well-explored in uranyl CPs regarding linker flexibility and rigidity, in which the choice of O-donor dicarboxylates may allow the construction of materials with interesting topologies. For example, the study of linker flexibility on uranyl structures using adipic acid or the study of linker rigidity on uranyl structures using BDC, NDC, and ADC has been documented. Moreover, the number of aromatic rings and the π-conjugation associated within such linkers may potentially enhance the number of noncovalent interactions (namely, π-π interactions) present within uranyl CPs and potentially direct the assembly of uranyl architectures.

elements.content: In addition to structural interests, we also explored how systematic pairings of O-donors and TPTZ may influence uranyl luminescence. Building off our earlier work using BPY or terpyridine (TPY) analogues and O-donor aromatic dicarboxylates, we reported that the triplet states of the O-donor linker or possibly π-stacking (as such observation has been shown to enhance uranyl luminescence) between adjacent N-donors may influence the observed emission in our materials. We herein report the synthesis, structures, and luminescence of a series of compounds containing differently sized ligands adipic acid, BDC, NDC, ADC, and an N-donor TPTZ guest to result in four novel structures: [UO2(C6H8O4)­(H2O)2]­(C18H12N6)2 (1), [UO2(C8H4O4)­(H2O)2]­(C18H12N6)2 (2), Na­[(UO2)­(C12H6O4)2]­(C18H13N6)­·H2O (3), and Na­[(UO2)­(C16H8O4)­(C6H3NO2)]­(C18H12N6)­·H2O (4).

Building off our earlier work using BPY or terpyridine (TPY) analogues and O-donor aromatic dicarboxylates, we reported that the triplet states of the O-donor linker or possibly π-stacking (as such observation has been shown to enhance uranyl luminescence) between adjacent N-donors may influence the observed emission in our materials. We herein report the synthesis, structures, and luminescence of a series of compounds containing differently sized ligands adipic acid, BDC, NDC, ADC, and an N-donor TPTZ guest to result in four novel structures: [UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2](C18H12N6)2 (1), [UO2(C8H4O4)(H2O)2](C18H12N6)2 (2), Na[(UO2)(C12H6O4)2](C18H13N6)⋅H2O (3), and Na[(UO2)(C16H8O4)(C6H3NO2)](C18H12N6)⋅H2O (4).

elements.content: Adipic acid, 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC), and naphthalene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (NDC) were purchased from VWR. 2,4,6-Tris­(2-pyridyl) s-triazine (TPTZ) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The ligand anthracene 9,10-dicarboxylic acid (ADC) was synthesized from literature methods and was characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy as reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Synthesis of Compounds 1-4 

Adipic acid, 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC), and naphthalene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (NDC) were purchased from VWR. 2,4,6-Tris(2-pyridyl) s-triazine (TPTZ) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The ligand anthracene 9,10-dicarboxylic acid (ADC) was synthesized from literature methods and was characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy as reported in the literature.

elements.content:
Caution: The uranyl acetate dihydrate (UO2(CH2COO)2­·2H2O) used in this study contains depleted uranium. Standard precautions for handling radioactive and toxic substances should be followed.

Compounds 1–3 were synthesized as follows: in a 25 mL Teflon-lined cup, the reagents UO2(CH3COO)2­·2H2O (106 mg, 0.251 mmol, 1 equiv), organic acid (0.377 mmol, 1.5 equiv), and TPTZ (116 mg, 0.377 mmol, 1.5 equiv), and 25 μL of 6 M NaOH were added to a solution of 2.5 mL of H2O-2-propanol mixture (1:1.5). The Teflon cup was then placed in a stainless steel Parr Bomb and heated statically at 120 °C for 5 days. The Parr bomb was then placed on a benchtop and allowed to cool to room temperature overnight. The synthesis of 4 follows a similar procedure as 1–3 except the temperature was changed to 150 °C, and the pH of the solution was adjusted with 100 μL of 6 M NaOH. Solids were isolated from the mother liquor onto a glass Petri dish and were washed with H2O, 2-propanol, and acetone, and then allowed to air-dry. Single crystals were then isolated and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The molar ratios and yields for each compound are listed in . A summary of the synthetic conditions and molar ratios of 1–4 can also be found in .

Single crystals were isolated from each bulk sample and mounted on MiTeGen micromounts. Reflections were collected using 0.5° φ and ω scans on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with an APEX II CCD detector using Mo Kα radiation at 100 K. All data were integrated using the SAINT software package, and an absorption correction was applied using SADABS. Structures were solved using direct methods (either SIR-92 or SHELXS-2013) and then refined using SHELXL-2013 within the WinGX software package, in which all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals were isolated from each bulk sample and mounted on MiTeGen micromounts. Reflections were collected using 0.5° φ and ω scans on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with an APEX II CCD detector using Mo Kα radiation at 100 K. All data were integrated using the SAINT  software package, and an absorption correction was applied using SADABS. Structures were solved using direct methods (either SIR-92 or SHELXS-2013) and then refined using SHELXL-2013 within the WinGX software package, in which all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically.

elements.content: Hydrogen atoms residing on the carbon atoms of TPTZ, BDC, NDC, and ADC were placed in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Efforts to model hydrogen atoms on the oxygen atoms of both coordinated and lattice water molecules in 1–4 were unsuccessful and thus not included in the final refinement. To confirm whether the bound oxygen atoms O2 and O2′ in both 1 and 2 were indeed water molecules (and not hydroxyl groups), bond valence summations were performed (see Supporting Information Tables S5 and S6) and are consistent with values for water molecules. Moreover, the U1–O2 bond distances in 1 and 2 were found to be 2.418(3) Å and 2.4104(16) Å respectively (see Supporting Information Tables S1 and S2) and are in agreement with the U–O bond distance range of 2.4–2.45 Å for coordinated water ligands. For compound 3, a hydrogen atom residing on the pyridyl nitrogen atom N6 in the TPTZ guest was observed within difference Fourier maps, yet placed in a calculated position using a riding model for refinement.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen atoms residing on the carbon atoms of TPTZ, BDC, NDC, and ADC were placed in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Efforts to model hydrogen atoms on the oxygen atoms of both coordinated and lattice water molecules in 1-4 were unsuccessful and thus not included in the final refinement. To confirm whether the bound oxygen atoms O2 and O2' in both 1 and 2 were indeed water molecules (and not hydroxyl groups), bond valence summations were performed (see Supporting Information Tables S5 and S6) and are consistent with values for water molecules. Moreover, the U1-O2 bond distances in 1 and 2 were found to be 2.418(3) Å and 2.4104(16) Å respectively (see Supporting Information Tables S1 and S2) and are in agreement with the U-O bond distance range of 2.4-2.45 Å for coordinated water ligands. For compound 3, a hydrogen atom residing on the pyridyl nitrogen atom N6 in the TPTZ guest was observed within difference Fourier maps, yet placed in a calculated position using a riding model for refinement.

elements.content: In all compounds, the π–π distances between TPTZ guests were determined using PLATON and also measured in Mercury (version 2.3). These distances can be found in . Tests for additional symmetry for 1–4 were performed using PLATON. A summary of the crystallographic data for 1–4 can be found in . ORTEP representations along with bond distance and angle tables can be found in the Supporting Information (Tables S1–S4 and Figures S1–S4). Crystallographic information files (CIFs) of compounds 1–4 were deposited to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) and can be obtained via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk by citing deposition numbers 1063979–1063981; 1405085.

Diffraction patterns for compounds 1–4 were obtained on a Rigaku MiniFlex II Desktop powder X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα, 3–60°) at room temperature and analyzed using the JADE software package. Purity for bulk samples of 1–4 was determined by comparing observed and calculated PXRD patterns. These patterns can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S5–S8). Our efforts to identify the impurities in 2 and 4 were unsuccessful, in which comparisons of the calculated patterns of BDC, TPTZ, and ADC as well as powder diffraction files (PDFs) of known uranium oxide and hydroxide phases (obtained from the International Centre of Diffraction Data, ICDD, version 2.0, 2002 within the JADE software package) were not indicative of the phase(s) present in 2 and 4. We therefore speculate unidentified uranium oxide or hydroxide phases may be present in the bulk sample as is often the case with hydrothermal syntheses.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

Diffraction patterns for compounds 1-4 were obtained on a Rigaku MiniFlex II Desktop powder X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα, 3-60°) at room temperature and analyzed using the JADE software package. Purity for bulk samples of 1-4 was determined by comparing observed and calculated PXRD patterns. These patterns can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S5-S8). Our efforts to identify the impurities in 2 and 4 were unsuccessful, in which comparisons of the calculated patterns of BDC, TPTZ, and ADC as well as powder diffraction files (PDFs) of known uranium oxide and hydroxide phases (obtained from the International Centre of Diffraction Data, ICDD, version 2.0, 2002 within the JADE software package) were not indicative of the phase(s) present in 2 and 4. We therefore speculate unidentified uranium oxide or hydroxide phases may be present in the bulk sample as is often the case with hydrothermal syntheses.

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 were crushed into fine powders and placed between two glass slides. Spectra were collected on a Horbia JobinYvon Fluorolog spectrophotometer using the face forward setting at 45° (298 K, excitation: 365 and 420 nm), and the excitation and emission slit widths were set to 1 nm (1, 2) or 5 nm (3, 4) in order to obtain suitable spectra at 298 K. The emission spectra for 1–4 at excitation wavelengths of 365 nm (3, 4) and 420 nm (1–4) can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S9–S14). Luminescence spectra of 2 and 4 were taken despite the presence of impurities in the bulk sample; thus interpretation of 2 and 4 must proceed with some restraint since the presence of unidentified impurities may affect the observed emission.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

Compounds 1-4 were crushed into fine powders and placed between two glass slides. Spectra were collected on a Horbia JobinYvon Fluorolog spectrophotometer using the face forward setting at 45° (298 K, excitation: 365 and 420 nm), and the excitation and emission slit widths were set to 1 nm (1, 2) or 5 nm (3, 4) in order to obtain suitable spectra at 298 K. The emission spectra for 1-4 at excitation wavelengths of 365 nm (3, 4) and 420 nm (1-4) can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S9-S14). Luminescence spectra of 2 and 4 were taken despite the presence of impurities in the bulk sample; thus interpretation of 2 and 4 must proceed with some restraint since the presence of unidentified impurities may affect the observed emission.

elements.content: The structure of 1 contains one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O1′) as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate adipic dicarboxylates via O3 (2.500(3) Å) and O4 (2.516(3) Å) as well as bound water molecules via O2 and O2′ (2.418(3) Å) to result in a UO8 hexagonal bipyramidal primary building unit. These units are linked by adipate anions to form chains that propagate in [100] (). The [UO2(C6H8O4)­(H2O)2] chains are separated by TPTZ guests, in which adjacent TPTZ molecules form π–π interactions via the pyridyl and triazyl rings (ring Cg–Cg distances 3.935(3) Å and 3.786(3) Å) respectively. Moreover, the nitrogen atoms N4, N5, and N6 on the pyridyl and pyrazyl rings of the TPTZ guest form donor–acceptor (D···A) interactions to the coordinated water ligand (O2···N4, 2.948(4) Å; O2···N5, 2.798(3) Å; and O2···N6, 2.814(3) Å) respectively as determined in Mercury and PLATON (). This hydrogen-bonding motif has been seen in a chain structure containing a TPTZ guest, succinic acid, and tin Sn­(IV), in which nitrogen atoms of the TPTZ form a similar “chelation pocket” with the bound water on Sn­(IV).
elements.clean_text:
Results

Structural Description

Crystal Structure of [UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2](C18H12N6)2 (1)

The structure of 1 contains one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O1') as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate adipic dicarboxylates via O3 (2.500(3) Å) and O4 (2.516(3) Å) as well as bound water molecules via O2 and O2' (2.418(3) Å) to result in a UO8 hexagonal bipyramidal primary building unit. These units are linked by adipate anions to form chains that propagate in [100] (). The [UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2] chains are separated by TPTZ guests, in which adjacent TPTZ molecules form π-π interactions via the pyridyl and triazyl rings (ring Cg-Cg distances 3.935(3) Å and 3.786(3) Å) respectively. Moreover, the nitrogen atoms N4, N5, and N6 on the pyridyl and pyrazyl rings of the TPTZ guest form donor-acceptor (D⋅⋅⋅A) interactions to the coordinated water ligand (O2⋅⋅⋅N4, 2.948(4) Å; O2⋅⋅⋅N5, 2.798(3) Å; and O2⋅⋅⋅N6, 2.814(3) Å) respectively as determined in Mercury and PLATON  (). This hydrogen-bonding motif has been seen in a chain structure containing a TPTZ guest, succinic acid, and tin Sn(IV), in which nitrogen atoms of the TPTZ form a similar "chelation pocket" with the bound water on Sn(IV).

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. Yellow polyhedra are [UO2]2+ centers, whereas red and blue spheres represent oxygen and nitrogen atoms, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1. Yellow polyhedra are [UO2]2+ centers, whereas red and blue spheres represent oxygen and nitrogen atoms, respectively.

elements.content: It is also noteworthy that compound 1 shares an identical chain motif as a reported uranyl adipate [UO2(C6H8O4)­(H2O)2] herein referred to as 1a. Notable differences, however, in the arrangement of the carbon chains and the orientation of the uranyl chains for 1 and 1a are observed. In compound 1a, “kinks” in the chain are observed within the C–C bonds, whereas in 1, the kinks are not present (), which suggests that the presence of TPTZ in 1 may influence the arrangement of the carbon skeleton. Further, parallel chains in 1a alternate between two different orientations rotated approximately 90° from each other compared to that of 1 (). This observation further suggests that the TPTZ molecules influence the packing of the chains.

elements.content: The structure of 2 consists of one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O1′) as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate BDC linkers via O3 (2.543(16) Å) and O4 (2.496(17) Å) and two bound water molecules (O2 and O2′; 2.410(16) Å) to result in a hexagonal bipyramidal UO8 building unit. These units are linked by the BDC anions to form [UO2(C8H8O4)­(H2O)2] chains that propagate in the [010] direction (). Similar to 1, the TPTZ guests reside between the chains and form π–π interactions between adjacent molecules via the pyridyl and triazyl rings (ring Cg–Cg distances 4.016(4) Å; 3.932(4) Å and 3.564(2) Å respectively) (). The TPTZ guests are arranged in an antiparallel orientation analogous to 1. Further, like 1, the TPTZ guests in 2 interact with the bound water molecules (O2) through the pyridyl and pyrazyl nitrogen atoms via H-bonding interactions (O2···N4, 2.955(2) Å; and O2···N5, 2.803(2) Å; and O2···N6, 2.814(2) Å) respectively ().

Crystal Structure of [UO2(C8H4O4)(H2O)2](C18H12N6)2 (2)

The structure of 2 consists of one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O1') as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate BDC linkers via O3 (2.543(16) Å) and O4 (2.496(17) Å) and two bound water molecules (O2 and O2'; 2.410(16) Å) to result in a hexagonal bipyramidal UO8 building unit. These units are linked by the BDC anions to form [UO2(C8H8O4)(H2O)2] chains that propagate in the [010] direction (). Similar to 1, the TPTZ guests reside between the chains and form π-π interactions between adjacent molecules via the pyridyl and triazyl rings (ring Cg-Cg distances 4.016(4) Å; 3.932(4) Å and 3.564(2) Å respectively) (). The TPTZ guests are arranged in an antiparallel orientation analogous to 1. Further, like 1, the TPTZ guests in 2 interact with the bound water molecules (O2) through the pyridyl and pyrazyl nitrogen atoms via H-bonding interactions (O2⋅⋅⋅N4, 2.955(2) Å; and O2⋅⋅⋅N5, 2.803(2) Å; and O2⋅⋅⋅N6, 2.814(2) Å) respectively ().

elements.content: The structure of 3 consists of one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O2) and two unique NDC molecules as seen in . U1 is bound by three bidentate NDC linkers via O3, O4, O7, O8, O9, and O10 (U–Oavg 2.477 Å) to result in a UO8 hexagonal bipyramidal building unit. These uranyl-NDC units are connected to one another through the NDC anions to generate sheets in the (010) plane (). Moreover, the NDC containing oxygen atoms O5 and O6 do not coordinate to uranyl centers, but rather O6 coordinates to a Na+ cation at a Na–O6 distance of 2.299(3) Å (). The O5 atom of the terminal NDC forms hydrogen bond interactions with the protonated TPTZ guest (N6···O5 2.644(3) Å) in an adjoining layer. The TPTZ guests do not form π–π interactions with each other, but instead such interactions are observed between NDC and the pyridyl ring of TPTZ (ring Cg–Cg distance: 3.796(2) Å) (). The protonation of TPTZ seen in 3 is not entirely surprising as such species have been observed previously. Also of note is that the Na+ cation binds to TPTZ via tridentate coordination through nitrogen atoms N1 (2.553(3) Å) N2 (2.467(3) Å) and N3 (2.615(3) Å) (). This is an uncommon feature and will be discussed further (below).

elements.content: The structure of 4 consists of one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O2) as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate ADC linkers via O3, O4, O5, and O6 (U–Oavg 2.502 Å), and one bidentate 2-pyridine carboxylic acid (PCA) via N7 (2.667(3) Å) and O7 (2.377(2) Å) to result in a UO7N1 hexagonal bipyramidal building unit. These units are linked by ADC anions to form [(UO2)­(C16H8O4)­(C6H3NO2)] chains that propagate approximately in [001] (). The TPTZ guests reside between the chains and form three different π–π interactions: (1) between two adjacent TPTZ guests (ring Cg–Cg distance 3.769(5) Å and (2) between TPTZ and the central ring of ADC (ring Cg–Cg distance: 3.509(2) Å), and (3) between TPTZ and the peripheral ring of ADC (ring Cg–Cg distance: 3.782(3) Å) as seen in . Like 1 and 2, the TPTZ guests in 4 are arranged in an antiparallel orientation.

Crystal Structure of Na[(UO2)(C16H8O4)(C6H3NO2)](C18H12N6)⋅H2O (4)

The structure of 4 consists of one crystallographically unique uranyl cation (U1, O1, O2) as seen in . U1 is bound by two bidentate ADC linkers via O3, O4, O5, and O6 (U-Oavg 2.502 Å), and one bidentate 2-pyridine carboxylic acid (PCA) via N7 (2.667(3) Å) and O7 (2.377(2) Å) to result in a UO7N1 hexagonal bipyramidal building unit. These units are linked by ADC anions to form [(UO2)(C16H8O4)(C6H3NO2)] chains that propagate approximately in [001] (). The TPTZ guests reside between the chains and form three different π-π interactions: (1) between two adjacent TPTZ guests (ring Cg-Cg distance 3.769(5) Å and (2) between TPTZ and the central ring of ADC (ring Cg-Cg distance: 3.509(2) Å), and (3) between TPTZ and the peripheral ring of ADC (ring Cg-Cg distance: 3.782(3) Å) as seen in . Like 1 and 2, the TPTZ guests in 4 are arranged in an antiparallel orientation.

elements.content: Analogous to 3, the sodium ion (Na1) present in 4 interacts with TPTZ via tridentate coordination through nitrogen atoms N4, N5, and N6 at bond distances of 2.567(3) Å, 2.478(3) Å, and 2.579(3) Å respectively (). Further, lattice water Ow1 binds to Na1 at a distance of 2.300(2) Å. The coordination of TPTZ to an alkali metal ion (Na+), as observed in 3 and 4, was an interesting result. To determine if a similar motif has been reported, a search in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.36, 2015) was performed. Our search revealed a structure containing a lithium (Li+) complex with bound TPTZ ligands via bidentate coordination, yet searches for structures containing sodium or potassium ions yielded no results. Thus, we present, to the best of our knowledge, two unique examples of TPTZ coordination to Na+ ions in 3 and 4 respectively.

Further, lattice water Ow1 binds to Na1 at a distance of 2.300(2) Å. The coordination of TPTZ to an alkali metal ion (Na+), as observed in 3 and 4, was an interesting result. To determine if a similar motif has been reported, a search in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.36, 2015) was performed. Our search revealed a structure containing a lithium (Li+) complex with bound TPTZ ligands via bidentate coordination, yet searches for structures containing sodium or potassium ions yielded no results. Thus, we present, to the best of our knowledge, two unique examples of TPTZ coordination to Na+ ions in 3 and 4 respectively.

elements.clean_text: 8  Structure of 4. Three instances of π-π interactions are observed in the structure: (1) between TPTZ guests, (2) between the central ring of ADC to TPTZ guest, and (3) between the peripheral ring of ADC to TPTZ guest.

elements.content: The presence of the PCA ligand in the crystal structure of 4 was an unanticipated result. A literature search reveals reports of metal-assisted hydrolysis of TPTZ using copper­(II) acetate­(halides) causing TPTZ to degrade to two byproducts: 2-pyridine carboxylic acid (PCA); and bis­(2-pyridyl-carbonyl)­amide under various experimental conditions. We therefore surmise that the presence of PCA in 4 is likely due to possible UO2 2+ assisted hydrolysis of TPTZ for the in situ generation of PCA. Moreover, similar phenomena have been observed in uranyl and lanthanide systems containing various O-donor dicarboxylates. One should also note the different synthetic parameters for the formation of 4 supports in situ generation of the PCA ligand. The amount of base (100 μL, 6 M NaOH) used to adjusted the pH in 4 is four times greater than that of 1–3, and the temperature used to make 4 (150 °C) differs from 1–3 (120 °C) (see ). We speculate that these harsher synthetic conditions may promote the formation of the PCA ligand in 4 as opposed to 1–3. We attempted to synthesize 4 using the same molar ratios, temperature (120 °C), and pH adjustment conditions (25 μL 6 M NaOH) as for 1–3, yet PXRD analysis reveals that 4 was not reproduced under those conditions.

elements.content: Many researchers have used combinations of ligand type to promote the formation of targeted topologies and properties. That was indeed our initial approach for the current study wherein we anticipated direct coordination of TPTZ to uranyl centers as observed previously. That said, the behavior of TPTZ as a noncoordinated species provides a platform for additional inquiry with respect to supramolecular interactions between these units, as well as their influence on assembly of the uranyl-carboxylate “hosts.” Of note is that TPTZ is more often observed as a coordinating species. A search of the CSD (version 5.36, 2015) using TPTZ and “any” metal yields 257 hits wherein all but a handful feature direct M-TPTZ coordination.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Many researchers have used combinations of ligand type to promote the formation of targeted topologies and properties. That was indeed our initial approach for the current study wherein we anticipated direct coordination of TPTZ to uranyl centers as observed previously. That said, the behavior of TPTZ as a noncoordinated species provides a platform for additional inquiry with respect to supramolecular interactions between these units, as well as their influence on assembly of the uranyl-carboxylate "hosts." Of note is that TPTZ is more often observed as a coordinating species. A search of the CSD (version 5.36, 2015) using TPTZ and "any" metal yields 257 hits wherein all but a handful feature direct M-TPTZ coordination.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 feature identical uranyl coordination geometries when using either adipic acid and BDC ( and ), yet display variations in the π-stacking distances between TPTZ guest molecules (). The distances between the pyridyl rings in 1 and 2 are similar (3.935(3) Å and 4.016(4); 3.932(4) Å), yet the π–π distances between the pyrazyl rings in 1 and 2 are not (3.786(3) Å, 3.564(2) Å respectively). These differences suggest linker choice (i.e., adipic acid and BDC) may influence the π-stacking interactions present in these structures.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 feature identical uranyl coordination geometries when using either adipic acid and BDC ( and ), yet display variations in the π-stacking distances between TPTZ guest molecules (). The distances between the pyridyl rings in 1 and 2 are similar (3.935(3) Å and 4.016(4); 3.932(4) Å), yet the π-π distances between the pyrazyl rings in 1 and 2 are not (3.786(3) Å, 3.564(2) Å respectively). These differences suggest linker choice (i.e., adipic acid and BDC) may influence the π-stacking interactions present in these structures.

elements.content: A departure from the linear chain motif in 1 and 2 is observed in 3 when two aromatic rings (NDC) are introduced to the O-donor ( and ). Similar to 1 and 2, the UO8 building unit is present, yet in 3 we observe three NDC linkers bound to each UO2 2+ cation results in a layered motif. We submit that the change in the global structure of 3 may be due to the size of NDC, and/or the presence of sodium ions. Unlike 1 and 2, the π–π interactions are present between a TPTZ guest and uranyl-O-donor (NDC) host (ring Cg–Cg distance: 3.796(2) Å).
elements.clean_text: A departure from the linear chain motif in 1 and 2 is observed in 3 when two aromatic rings (NDC) are introduced to the O-donor ( and ). Similar to 1 and 2, the UO8 building unit is present, yet in 3 we observe three NDC linkers bound to each UO2 2+ cation results in a layered motif. We submit that the change in the global structure of 3 may be due to the size of NDC, and/or the presence of sodium ions. Unlike 1 and 2, the π-π interactions are present between a TPTZ guest and uranyl-O-donor (NDC) host (ring Cg-Cg distance: 3.796(2) Å).

elements.content: The introduction of three aromatic rings (ADC), as well as the unanticipated PCA ligand, changes the global structure further to result in a 1-D chain structural motif in 4 ( and ). Similar to 1 and 2, π–π distances between adjacent TPTZ guests are observed (3.769(5) Å). These distances in 4 are shorter compared to the π–π distances of TPTZ guests in 1 and 2 using adipic acid and BDC respectively (). Similar to 3, π–π interactions between the uranyl-ADC host and TPTZ (3.502(2) Å; 3.782(3) Å) in 4 were observed and are shorter than the interaction between the uranyl host and TPTZ containing NDC (3, 3.796(2) Å). These results suggest ADC may influence π–π distances more significantly than NDC, BDC, or adipic acid and may possibly induce additional interactions with varying π-stacking distances given the number of aromatic rings present in ADC. Moreover, one should not ignore the presence of sodium ions and its coordination to TPTZ in 3 and 4, which may additionally influence the interactions.

elements.content: The luminescence of the UO2 2+ cation has been described as green emission with five or six vibronic peaks ranging from 450 to 650 nm. These peaks arise from electronic transitions between the LUMO 5f nonbonding uranyl orbitals and the HOMO U–O hybrid sigma bonding orbital. Further, these electronic transitions are coupled to vibratonal relaxation S11 → S01 and S10 → S0v (v = 0–4) states within the UO axial bond. Luminescence spectra of 1–4 was taken at two excitation wavelengths 365 and 420 nm, which correspond to the U–O equatorial ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) band and UO axial LMCT band respectively as observed in the absorption spectrum of UO2 2+.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Studies

The luminescence of the UO2 2+ cation has been described as green emission with five or six vibronic peaks ranging from 450 to 650 nm. These peaks arise from electronic transitions between the LUMO 5f nonbonding uranyl orbitals and the HOMO U-O hybrid sigma bonding orbital. Further, these electronic transitions are coupled to vibratonal relaxation S11 → S01 and S10 → S0v  (v = 0-4) states within the UO axial bond. Luminescence spectra of 1-4 was taken at two excitation wavelengths 365 and 420 nm, which correspond to the U-O equatorial ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) band and UO axial LMCT band respectively as observed in the absorption spectrum of UO2 2+.

elements.content: The luminescence of 1 and 2 shows typical UO2 2+ emission with five vibronic peaks between 400 and 650 nm at both 365 and 420 nm excitation wavelengths (, see Supporting Information Figures S9–S10). Compounds 3 and 4 however show weak uranyl emission (or the lack thereof) at both 365 and 420 nm excitation wavelengths (see Supporting Information Figures S11–S14).

Compounds 3 and 4 however show weak uranyl emission (or the lack thereof) at both 365 and 420 nm excitation wavelengths (see Supporting Information Figures S11-S14).

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra of 1 (red) and 2 (blue) taken at room temperature (excitation: 365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 10  Solid-state emission spectra of 1 (red) and 2 (blue) taken at room temperature (excitation: 365 nm).

elements.content: The emission of 1 shows an average red shift of 6 nm relative to that of 2 (excitation: 365 nm, 298 K, , see Supporting Information Table S1). This shift is consistent with our previous study in which substitution between N-donor TPY ligands and different O-donor aromatic linkers within binuclear pseudo dimers show an emission shift of 2 nm (80 cm–1). It is noteworthy the emission shift value between 1 and 2 is significantly larger than present in our previously reported uranyl pseudo dimers. This observation suggests that linker choice (aliphatic vs aromatic) 1 and 2 may be responsible for the large shift and may influence uranyl electronic structure.
elements.clean_text: The emission of 1 shows an average red shift of 6 nm relative to that of 2 (excitation: 365 nm, 298 K, , see Supporting Information Table S1). This shift is consistent with our previous study in which substitution between N-donor TPY ligands and different O-donor aromatic linkers within binuclear pseudo dimers show an emission shift of 2 nm (80 cm-1). It is noteworthy the emission shift value between 1 and 2 is significantly larger than present in our previously reported uranyl pseudo dimers. This observation suggests that linker choice (aliphatic vs aromatic) 1 and 2 may be responsible for the large shift and may influence uranyl electronic structure.

elements.content: The lack of emission observed in 3 is likely due to back energy transfer given the triplet state of NDC (20 450 cm–1) is below the emissive level of UO2 2+ (21 321 cm–1) as discussed in our earlier work. The absence of UO2 2+ emission in 4 may be the result of a similar nonradiative pathway as in 3. We were unable to find a literature value for the triplet state of ADC, and our attempts to determine such experimentally were unsuccessful due to the insolubility of ADC in common solvents at room temperature. However, the triplet state of anthracene 9-monocarboxylic acid (AMC) is known (13 790 cm–1), and as such, one may infer the triplet state of ADC may be lowered further due to the presence of an additional carboxylate.

The absence of UO2 2+ emission in 4 may be the result of a similar nonradiative pathway as in 3. We were unable to find a literature value for the triplet state of ADC, and our attempts to determine such experimentally were unsuccessful due to the insolubility of ADC in common solvents at room temperature. However, the triplet state of anthracene 9-monocarboxylic acid (AMC) is known (13790 cm-1), and as such, one may infer the triplet state of ADC may be lowered further due to the presence of an additional carboxylate.

elements.content: A systematic study was undertaken in which differently sized O-donor linkers (adipic acid, BDC, NDC, and ADC) were used to construct uranyl CPs containing TPTZ guest molecules. These materials were synthesized and characterized using single crystal X-ray diffraction, PXRD, and luminescence spectroscopy. We observe that the addition of aromatic rings in the linkers offers an opportunity to explore the number of π–π interactions and varying degrees of π-stacking distances between TPTZ guests or between the TPTZ guest and the host framework. The luminescent properties in 1–4 suggest a dependence on O-donor linker species.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A systematic study was undertaken in which differently sized O-donor linkers (adipic acid, BDC, NDC, and ADC) were used to construct uranyl CPs containing TPTZ guest molecules. These materials were synthesized and characterized using single crystal X-ray diffraction, PXRD, and luminescence spectroscopy. We observe that the addition of aromatic rings in the linkers offers an opportunity to explore the number of π-π interactions and varying degrees of π-stacking distances between TPTZ guests or between the TPTZ guest and the host framework. The luminescent properties in 1-4 suggest a dependence on O-donor linker species.
